title: If all the polar ice caps were to melt, which land areas would remain habitable and non-submerged? - Quora

response.answer_text: Two different questions. Melting polar ice would mean sea levels will rise upwards of 25 meters higher than present, but there will still be big parts of the earth that are above the new sea level. That doesn’t mean that any of the earth will be ‘habitable’ at least for humans. melting of the icecaps would cause the release of hundreds of gigatons of methane currently kept in place by the polar ice-caps. Methane is a far more effective greenhouse gas than mere c02, and best guess of organizations like the Arctic Methane Emergency Group is that temperatures could go up to 10 C above baseline. That’s a temperature too high for most food grains to propagate, and ocean temperatures would be high enough to wipe out the phytoplankton, which supplies half our planet’s oxygen. When Habitat packs it in

90–95% of the land would still be above water. But here’s a map of where. What the World Would Look Like if All the Ice Melted  It’s also worth noting, that human caused climate change, even at it’s worst, would only be able to melt about half the worlds ice.
